content.description:
A water tank at Camp Newton holds 1200 gallons of water at time t = 0. During the time interval 0≤t≤18 hours, water is pumped into the tank at the rate  

<math> <mrow> <mi>W</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>95</mn> <msqrt> <mi>t</mi> </msqrt> <msup> <mrow> <mi>sin</mi> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mi>t</mi> <mn>6</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math> gallons per hour.

During the same time interval, water is removed from the tank at the rate 

<math> <mrow> <mi>R</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>275</mn> <msup> <mrow> <mi>sin</mi> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mi>t</mi> <mn>3</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math> gallons per hour.
content.question: For t>18, no water is pumped into the tank, but water continues to be removed at the rate R(t) until the tank becomes empty. Let k be the time at which the tank becomes empty. Write, but do not solve, an equation involving an integral expression that can be used to find the value of k.

frqParts.text: For t>18, no water is pumped into the tank, but water continues to be removed at the rate R(t) until the tank becomes empty. Let k be the time at which the tank becomes empty. Write, but do not solve, an equation involving an integral expression that can be used to find the value of k.

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
